_\$EM

Y?

&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Effective April 2, 2012, Ante5, Inc. changed&#13;its corporate name to Black Ridge Oil &amp;#38; Gas, Inc., and continues to trade its common stock on the OTCQB under the&#13;trading symbol &amp;#147;ANFC&amp;#148;. Black Ridge Oil &amp;#38; Gas, Inc. (Formerly Ante5, Inc.) (the &amp;#147;Company&amp;#148;) became an&#13;independent company in April 2010 when the spin-off from our former parent company, Ante4, Inc. (now Emerald Oil, Inc. and also&#13;formerly known as Voyager Oil &amp;#38; Gas, Inc.), became effective. We became a publicly traded company when our shares began trading&#13;on July 1, 2010. Since October 2010, we have been engaged in the business of acquiring oil and gas leases and participating in&#13;the drilling of wells in the Bakken and Three Forks trends in North Dakota and Montana. Our strategy is to participate in the exploration,&#13;development and production of oil and gas reserves as a non-operating working interest owner in a growing, diversified portfolio&#13;of oil and gas wells. We aggressively seek to accumulate mineral leases to position us to participate in the drilling of new wells&#13;on a continuous basis. Occasionally we also purchase working interests in producing wells.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company&amp;#146;s focus is the acquisition,&#13;exploration, development and production of crude oil and natural gas properties, primarily in the Bakken and Three Forks trends&#13;in North Dakota and Montana. We believe that our prospective success revolves around our ability to acquire mineral rights and&#13;participate in drilling activities by virtue of our ownership of such rights and through the relationships we have developed with&#13;our operating partners.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Basis of Accounting&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Our  financial statements are prepared&#13;using the accrual method of accounting as generally accepted in the United States of America (U.S. GAAP) and the rules of the Securities&#13;and Exchange Commission (SEC).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Segment Reporting&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;FASB ASC 280-10-50 requires annual and interim&#13;reporting for an enterprise&amp;#146;s operating segments and related disclosures about its products, services, geographic areas and&#13;major customers. An operating segment is defined as a component of an enterprise that engages in business activities from which&#13;it may earn revenues and expenses, and about which separate financial information is regularly evaluated by the chief operating&#13;decision maker in deciding how to allocate resources. The Company operates as a single segment and will evaluate additional segment&#13;disclosure requirements as it expands its operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Reclassifications&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In the current year, the&#13;Company separately classified advances to operators from prepaid expenses in the Balance Sheet and classified advances to&#13;operators as an investing activity on the Statement of Cash Flows. For comparative purposes, amounts in prior periods have been&#13;reclassified to conform to current year presentation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.15in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.15in&gt;&lt;u&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The preparation of financial statements in conformity&#13;with generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts&#13;of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported&#13;amount of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The oil and gas industry is subject, by its&#13;nature, to environmental hazards and clean-up costs. At this time, management knows of no substantial losses from environmental&#13;accidents or events for which the Company may be currently liable.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.15in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.15in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.15in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.15in&gt;&lt;u&gt;Cash and&#13;Cash Equivalents&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Cash equivalents include money market accounts&#13;which have maturities of three months or less. For the purpose of the statements of cash flows, all highly liquid investments with&#13;an original maturity of three months or less are considered to be cash equivalents. Cash equivalents are stated at cost plus accrued&#13;interest, which approximates market value. Cash and cash equivalents consist of the following:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=6 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;December 31,&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2013&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 72%; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Cash&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 11%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;1,112,356&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 11%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;513,788&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Money market funds&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;37,991&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;903,552&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-indent: 13.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Total&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;1,150,347&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;1,417,340&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Cash in Excess of FDIC and SIPC Insured Limits&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company maintains its cash in bank deposit&#13;accounts which, at times, may exceed federally insured limits. Accounts are guaranteed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation&#13;(FDIC) and the Securities Investor Protection Corporation (SIPC) up to $250,000 and $500,000, respectively, under current regulations.&#13;The Company had approximately $862,356 and $917,340 in excess of FDIC and SIPC insured limits at December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&#13;The Company has not experienced any losses in such accounts.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Debt Issuance Costs&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Costs relating to obtaining certain debts are&#13;capitalized and amortized over the term of the related debt using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest&#13;method. The Company paid $865,101 and $796,233 of debt issuance costs during the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively,&#13;of which the unamortized balance of debt issuance costs at December 31, 2013 and 2012 was $772,883 and $657,702, respectively.&#13;Amortization of debt issuance costs charged to interest expense was $749,920 and $190,580 for the years ended December 31, 2013&#13;and 2012, respectively. When a loan is paid in full, any unamortized financing costs are removed from the related accounts and&#13;charged to interest expense.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Website Development Costs&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company accounts for website development&#13;costs in accordance with ASC 350-50, &amp;#147;Accounting for Website Development Costs&amp;#148; (&amp;#147;ASC 350-50&amp;#148;), wherein&#13;website development costs are segregated into three activities:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: top&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 24px&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 24px&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;1)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Initial stage (planning), whereby the related costs are expensed.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: top&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 24px&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 24px&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Development (web application, infrastructure, graphics), whereby the related costs are capitalized and amortized once the website is ready for use. Costs for development content of the website may be expensed or capitalized depending on the circumstances of the expenditures.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: top&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 24px&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 24px&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;3)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Post-implementation (after site is up and running: security, training, admin), whereby the related costs are expensed as incurred. Upgrades are usually expensed, unless they add additional functionality.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;We have capitalized a total of $56,660 of website&#13;development costs from inception through December 31, 2013. We have recognized depreciation expense on these website costs of $18,887&#13;and $18,630 for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company recognizes deferred tax assets and&#13;liabilities based on differences between the financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities using the enacted tax&#13;rates and laws that are expected to be in effect when the differences are expected to be recovered. The Company provides a valuation&#13;allowance for deferred tax assets for which it does not consider realization of such assets to be more likely than not.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Fair Value of Financial Instruments&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Under FASB ASC 820-10-05, the Financial Accounting&#13;Standards Board establishes a framework for measuring fair value in generally accepted accounting principles and expands disclosures&#13;about fair value measurements. This Statement reaffirms that fair value is the relevant measurement attribute. The adoption of&#13;this standard did not have a material effect on the Company&amp;#146;s financial statements as reflected herein. The carrying amounts&#13;of cash, accounts payable and accrued expenses reported on the balance sheets are estimated by management to approximate fair value&#13;primarily due to the short term nature of the instruments. The Company had no items that required fair value measurement on a recurring&#13;basis.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Non-Oil &amp;#38; Gas Property and Equipment&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Property and equipment that are not oil and&#13;gas properties are recorded at cost and depreciated using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives of three to&#13;seven years. Expenditures for replacements, renewals, and betterments are capitalized. Maintenance and repairs are charged to operations&#13;as incurred. Long-lived assets, other than oil and gas properties, are evaluated for impairment to determine if current circumstances&#13;and market conditions indicate the carrying amount may not be recoverable. The Company has not recognized any impairment losses&#13;on non-oil and gas long-lived assets. Depreciation expense was $24,001 and $24,206 for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012,&#13;respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Revenue Recognition and Gas Balancing&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company recognizes oil and gas revenues&#13;from its interests in producing wells when production is delivered to, and title has transferred to, the purchaser and to the extent&#13;the selling price is reasonably determinable. The Company uses the sales method of accounting for gas balancing of gas production&#13;and would recognize a liability if the existing proven reserves were not adequate to cover the current imbalance situation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Asset Retirement Obligations&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company records the fair value of a liability&#13;for an asset retirement obligation in the period in which the well is spud or the asset is acquired and a corresponding increase&#13;in the carrying amount of the related long-lived asset. The liability is accreted to its present value each period, and the capitalized&#13;cost is depreciated over the useful life of the related asset. If the liability is settled for an amount other than the recorded&#13;amount, a gain or loss is recognized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.15in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.15in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Full Cost Method&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company follows the full cost method of&#13;accounting for oil and gas operations whereby all costs related to the exploration and development of oil and gas properties are&#13;initially capitalized into a single cost center (&amp;#34;full cost pool&amp;#34;). Such costs include land acquisition costs, geological&#13;and geophysical expenses, carrying charges on non-producing properties, costs of drilling directly related to acquisition, and&#13;exploration activities. Internal costs that are capitalized are directly attributable to acquisition, exploration and development&#13;activities and do not include costs related to the production, general corporate overhead or similar activities. Costs associated&#13;with production and general corporate activities are expensed in the period incurred. Capitalized costs are summarized as follows&#13;for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=6 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Years Ended December 31,&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2013&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 72%; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Capitalized Certain Payroll and Other Internal Costs&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 11%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;137,509&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 11%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;172,503&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Capitalized Interest Costs&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;&amp;#150;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;&amp;#150;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-indent: 12.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Total&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;137,509&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;172,503&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Proceeds from property sales will generally&#13;be credited to the full cost pool, with no gain or loss recognized, unless such a sale would significantly alter the relationship&#13;between capitalized costs and the proved reserves attributable to these costs. A significant alteration would typically involve&#13;a sale of 20% or more of the proved reserves related to a single full cost pool. During the year ended December 31, 2013, the Company&#13;sold approximately 189 net acres for total proceeds of $608,387. During the year ended December 31, 2012, the Company sold approximately&#13;509 net acres for total proceeds of $1,893,649. The Company assesses all items classified as unevaluated property on a quarterly&#13;basis for possible impairment or reduction in value. The assessment includes consideration of the following factors, among others:&#13;intent to drill; remaining lease term; geological and geophysical evaluations; drilling results and activity; the assignment of&#13;proved reserves; and the economic viability of development if proved reserves are assigned. During any period in which these factors&#13;indicate an impairment, the cumulative drilling costs incurred to date for such property and all or a portion of the associated&#13;leasehold costs are transferred to the full cost pool and are then subject to amortization.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Capitalized costs associated with impaired properties&#13;and properties having proved reserves, estimated future development costs, and asset retirement costs under FASB ASC 410-20-25&#13;are depleted and amortized on the unit-of-production method based on the estimated gross proved reserves as determined by independent&#13;petroleum engineers. The costs of unproved properties are withheld from the depletion base until such time as they are either developed&#13;or abandoned.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Capitalized costs of oil and gas properties&#13;(net of related deferred income taxes) may not exceed an amount equal to the present value, discounted at 10% per annum, of the&#13;estimated future net cash flows from proved oil and gas reserves plus the cost of unproved properties (adjusted for related income&#13;tax effects). Should capitalized costs exceed this ceiling, impairment is recognized. The present value of estimated future net&#13;cash flows is computed by applying the arithmetic average first day price of oil and natural gas for the preceding twelve months&#13;to estimated future production of proved oil and gas reserves as of the end of the period, less estimated future expenditures to&#13;be incurred in developing and producing the proved reserves and assuming continuation of existing economic conditions. Such present&#13;value of proved reserves' future net cash flows excludes future cash outflows associated with settling asset retirement obligations.&#13;Should this comparison indicate an excess carrying value, the excess is charged to earnings as an impairment expense. We recognized&#13;no impairment costs during the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Concentrations&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Our revenue is solely derived from oil and gas&#13;sales to various purchasers, the market for which has very inelastic demand. Due to this, we do not consider any purchasers to&#13;represent a material concentration to our sales for the years ended December 31, 2013 or 2012, as we believe any of our customers&#13;could easily be replaced.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Since we do not operate any of our wells, we&#13;depend on our drilling partner operators to perform the drilling and other operating activities required for all sales of oil and&#13;gas. These operators are also responsible for remitting to us our revenue proceeds and billing us for drilling costs and lease&#13;operating expenses incurred. We had material concentrations of accounts receivable owed from four (4) and two (2) operators during&#13;the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively, representing 60% and 44% of total oil and gas revenues and 41% and 28%&#13;of total oil and gas accounts receivable as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively. As of December 31, 2013 and 2012, we had&#13;153 and 66 gross producing wells, respectively, and 4.87 and 2.30 net producing wells, respectively. As of December 31, 2013 and&#13;2012, these four (4) and two (2) operating partners operated 31% and 38% of these gross producing wells, respectively, and 37%&#13;and 38% of these net producing wells, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Basic and Diluted Loss Per Share&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Basic earnings per share (&amp;#147;EPS&amp;#148;)&#13;are computed by dividing net income (the numerator) by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period&#13;(the denominator). Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted average number of common shares and potential&#13;common shares outstanding (if dilutive) during each period. Potential common shares include stock options, warrants and restricted&#13;stock. The number of potential common shares outstanding relating to stock options, warrants and restricted stock is computed using&#13;the treasury stock method.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The reconciliation of the denominators used&#13;to calculate basic EPS and diluted EPS for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=6 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Years Ended December 31,&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2013&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 72%; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Weighted average common shares outstanding &amp;#150; basic&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 11%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;47,979,990&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 11%; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;47,789,225&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=width: 1%&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Plus: Potentially dilutive common shares:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 13.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Stock options and warrants&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;&amp;#150;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;272,014&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Weighted average common shares outstanding &amp;#150; diluted&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;47,979,990&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;48,061,239&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Stock options and warrants excluded from the&#13;calculation of diluted EPS because their effect was anti-dilutive were 16,103,209 and 7,513,709 as of December 31, 2013 and 2012,&#13;respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; background-color: white&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; background-color: white&gt;&lt;u&gt;Stock-Based Compensation&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company adopted FASB guidance on stock based&#13;compensation upon inception at April 9, 2010. Under FASB ASC 718-10-30-2, all share-based payments to employees, including grants&#13;of employee stock options, are to be recognized in the income statement based on their fair values. Pro forma disclosure is no&#13;longer an alternative. Amortization of the fair values of common stock and stock options issued for services and compensation totaled&#13;$643,817 and $1,288,448 for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively, including $-0- and $438,539, respectively,&#13;of common stock valued at the fair market value based on the Company&amp;#146;s closing trading price on the date of grant. The fair&#13;values of stock options were determined using the Black-Scholes options pricing model and an effective term of 6 to 6.5 years based&#13;on the weighted average of the vesting periods and the stated term of the option grants and the discount rate on 5 to 7 year U.S.&#13;Treasury securities at the grant date and are being amortized over the related implied service term, or vesting period.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;u&gt;Uncertain Tax Positions&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Effective upon inception at April 9, 2010, the&#13;Company adopted new standards for accounting for uncertainty in income taxes. These standards prescribe a recognition threshold&#13;and measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken or expected to be taken&#13;in a tax return. These standards also provide guidance on de-recognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in&#13;interim periods, disclosure, and transition.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Various taxing authorities can periodically&#13;audit the Company&amp;#146;s income tax returns. These audits include questions regarding the Company&amp;#146;s tax filing positions,&#13;including the timing and amount of deductions and the allocation of income to various tax jurisdictions. In evaluating the exposures&#13;connected with these various tax filing positions, including state and local taxes, the Company records allowances for probable&#13;exposures. A number of years may elapse before a particular matter, for which an allowance has been established, is audited and&#13;fully resolved. The Company has not yet undergone an examination by any taxing authorities.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The assessment of the Company&amp;#146;s tax position&#13;relies on the judgment of management to estimate the exposures associated with the Company&amp;#146;s various filing positions.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Recent Accounting Pronouncements&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Recently Adopted&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;Balance Sheet Offsetting&lt;/i&gt; &amp;#151; In December&#13;2011, the FASB issued Balance Sheet (Topic 210) &amp;#151; Disclosures about Offsetting Assets and Liabilities (ASU 2011-11), which&#13;requires disclosures regarding netting arrangements in agreements underlying derivatives, certain financial instruments and related&#13;collateral amounts, and the extent to which an entity&amp;#146;s financial statement presentation policies related to netting arrangements&#13;impact amounts recorded to the financial statements. These disclosure requirements do not affect the presentation of amounts in&#13;the balance sheets, and are effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013, and interim periods within&#13;those annual reporting periods. We implemented the disclosure guidance effective January 1, 2013 and the implementation did not&#13;have a material effect on our financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0&gt;&lt;i&gt;Recent Accounting Pronouncements Not Yet Adopted&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Various accounting standards and interpretations&#13;were issued in 2013 with effective dates subsequent to December 31, 2013. We have evaluated the recently issued accounting pronouncements&#13;that are effective in 2014 and believe that none of them will have a material effect on our financial position, results of operations&#13;or cash flows when adopted.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;During the years ended December 31, 2013 and&#13;2012, we granted various awards to our Officers and Directors as compensation for their services. These related party grants are&#13;fully disclosed in Note 12 below.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Former Financing Arrangement&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On May 2, 2011, we entered into a Revolving&#13;Credit and Security Agreement (the &amp;#147;PrenAnte5 Credit Agreement&amp;#148;) with certain lenders (collectively, the &amp;#147;Lenders&amp;#148;&#13;and individually a &amp;#147;Lender&amp;#148;) and Prenante5, LLC, as agent for the Lenders (PrenAnte5, LLC, in such capacity, the &amp;#147;Agent&amp;#148;).&#13;The facility provided $10 million in financing to be made available for drilling projects on the Company&amp;#146;s North Dakota Bakken&#13;and Three Forks position. The Company drew $2,000,000 utilizing the PrenAnte5 Credit Agreement in February of 2012 and subsequently&#13;paid in full and terminated the agreement in April of 2012.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;Morris Goldfarb, one of the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;former directors, participated as a Lender through the Agent with a commitment amount of $1.5 million in the facility. In consideration&#13;for his participation through the agent, Mr. Goldfarb was issued 75,000 warrants (his pro-rata share as a Lender) with the same&#13;terms and conditions as the other warrants issued in connection with the closing of the PrenAnte5 Credit Agreement. The warrants&#13;vested on the May 2, 2012, the one year anniversary of the grant and are exercisable until May 1, 2016 at an exercise price of&#13;$0.95 per share. The total estimated value using the Black-Scholes Pricing Model, based on a volatility rate of 97% and a call&#13;option value of $0.7837, was $58,781, and was amortized over the three year life of the credit agreement and the amortization was&#13;accelerated in 2012 to fully amortize the remaining unamortized value upon termination of the agreement. The Company recognized&#13;compensation expense of $-0- and $45,719 during the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Other Related Party Transactions&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;A former officer of the Company, Steve Lipscomb,&#13;received a commission of 5% of a royalty stream from Peerless Media Ltd., recorded on the balance sheet as of December 31, 2011&#13;as a contingent consideration receivable, as a result of an incentive arrangement with Mr. Lipscomb that was approved by Ante4&amp;#146;s&#13;Board of Directors in February 2009. Mr. Lipscomb has received a total of $-0- and $26,468 during the years ended December 31,&#13;2013 and 2012, respectively, of which $19,071 in royalties were received by Mr. Lipscomb while an officer of the Company in 2012.&#13;As a result of the settlement of litigation related to the same agreement, Mr. Lipscomb was due 5% of the settlement payments from&#13;the litigation settlement amounting to approximately $548,827 of which $432,593 was paid in 2012 and the remaining $116,234 was&#13;paid by the Company of the final settlement payment from Peerless Media, Ltd. Mr. Lipscomb received an additional $19,477 in 2013&#13;for his 5% share in additional settlement payments received by the Company in 2013.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company has asset retirement obligations&#13;associated with the future plugging and abandonment of proved properties and related facilities. Under the provisions of FASB ASC&#13;410-20-25, the fair value of a liability for an asset retirement obligation is recorded in the period in which it is incurred and&#13;a corresponding increase in the carrying amount of the related long lived asset. The liability is accreted to its present value&#13;each period, and the capitalized cost is depreciated over the useful life of the related asset. If the liability is settled for&#13;an amount other than the recorded amount, a gain or loss is recognized. The Company has no assets that are legally restricted for&#13;purposes of settling asset retirement obligations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The following table summarizes the Company&amp;#146;s asset retirement&#13;obligation transactions recorded in accordance with the provisions of FASB ASC 410-20-25 during the years ended December 31, 2013&#13;and 2012:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Peerless Settlement&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;As a result of a transaction between Ante4,&#13;Inc. (&amp;#147;Ante4&amp;#148;) and Peerless Media Ltd. (&amp;#147;Peerless&amp;#148;) during fiscal year 2009, pursuant to which, Ante4 sold&#13;substantially all of its operating assets (the &amp;#147;Transaction&amp;#148;) and a spin-off on April 16, 2010 to Ante5, Inc., now&#13;Black Ridge Oil &amp;#38; Gas, Inc. (the &amp;#147;Company&amp;#148;), the Company was entitled to receive, in perpetuity, 5% of gross gaming&#13;revenue and 5% of other revenue of Peerless generated by Ante4&amp;#146;s former business and assets that were sold to Peerless in&#13;the Transaction, subject to a 5% commission presented as Royalties Payable on the balance sheet. Peerless had guaranteed a minimum&#13;payment to the Company of $3 million for such revenue over the three-year period following the closing of the Transaction on November&#13;2, 2009. The Company prepared a discounted cash flow model to determine an estimated fair value of this portion of the purchase&#13;price as of November 2, 2009. This value was recorded on the balance sheet of Ante4. In connection with the spin-off described&#13;above, on April 16, 2010 Ante4 distributed this asset to its wholly-owned subsidiary, Ante5, Inc., which was spun-off and a registration&#13;statement was filed on Form 10-12/A, along with an Information Statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the purpose&#13;of spinning off the Ante5 shares from Ante4, Inc. to its stockholders of record on April 15, 2010. The following is a summary of&#13;the contingency consideration receivable and related royalties payable through December 31, 2012:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman

   &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;6,148,400&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;(529,361)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;26,468&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;(502,893)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Elimination of the contingent receivable due to settlement agreement&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;(5,479,241)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;273,963&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;(5,205,278)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Balance, December 31, 2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1.5pt double; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1.5pt double; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1.5pt double; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1.5pt double; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; border-bottom: black 1.5pt double; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; border-bottom: black 1.5pt double; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;-&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;On September 27, 2012, the Company entered into&#13;a settlement agreement with Peerless and ElectraWorks, Ltd. (&amp;#147;ElectraWorks&amp;#148;) to settle all claims regarding Peerless&amp;#146;s&#13;performance of obligations with respect to the business purchased by Peerless from Ante4, Inc. in November 2009 (the &amp;#34;Litigation&amp;#34;).&#13;The Litigation was pending before Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services (JAMS) in Los Angeles, California. Under the settlement&#13;agreement, Peerless/ElectraWorks will pay the Company $13.5 million, of which $11,000,000 was received by the Company in 2012 and&#13;the remaining $2.5 million was received in 2013. In addition, Peerless/ElectraWorks will make payments to the Company upon certain&#13;contingencies related to the passage of federal or state legislation permitting real money online poker and Peerless/ElectraWorks&#13;or one of their affiliates obtaining such a license. The maximum amount of these contingent payments is $6.5 million with the amount&#13;determined based on how such legislation is enacted. Under the settlement agreement the Company has released its rights to the&#13;royalty stream and no further payments are due from Peerless/ElectraWorks other than those set forth in the settlement agreement.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company paid attorneys&amp;#146; fees of $2&#13;million, of which $1.84 million was paid in 2012 and $0.16 million was paid in 2013, as well as various costs out of the proceeds.&#13;In addition, as a result of an incentive arrangement with Steve Lipscomb, a former officer of the Company that was approved by&#13;WPT Enterprises, Inc.&amp;#146;s Board of Directors in February 2009, Mr. Lipscomb is receiving 5% of the settlement payments, net&#13;of attorneys&amp;#146; fees and other costs; as such amounts are received by the Company.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The contingent consideration receivable of $5,479,241&#13;and the royalty payable of $273,963 as of the settlement date were relieved as a part of the settlement resulting in a net gain&#13;of $5,745,895. The Company has expensed non-contingent expenses and fees associated with pursuing the settlement as those expenses&#13;and fees were incurred amounting to $-0- and $333,176 for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In December of 2013, as a result of the legalization&#13;of online gambling in the state of New Jersey, Peerless/ElectraWorks paid the Company $380,982 of additional settlement proceeds.&#13;As part of the agreement with Mr. Lipscomb, the Company paid Mr. Lipscomb 5% of the settlement proceeds or $19,477.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;u&gt;Deloitte &amp;#38; Touche Settlement&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company is required to recognize all derivative&#13;instruments on the balance sheet as either assets or liabilities measured at fair value. The Company has not designated its derivative&#13;instruments as hedges for accounting purposes and, as such, marks its derivative instruments to fair value and recognizes the realized&#13;and unrealized changes in fair value in its statements of operations under the captions &amp;#147;Loss on Settled Derivatives&amp;#148;&#13;and &amp;#147;Losses on the mark-to-market of derviatives.&amp;#148;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company has utilized swap and collar derivative&#13;contracts to hedge against the variability in cash flows associated with the forecasted sale of crude oil production. While the&#13;use of these derivative instruments limits the downside risk of adverse price movements, their use also limits the upside revenue&#13;potential of upward price movements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;For a fixed price swap contract, the counterparty&#13;is required to make a payment to the Company if the settlement price for any settlement period is less than the swap price and&#13;the Company is required to make a payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any period is greater than the swap price.&#13;For a collar contract, the counterparty is required to make a payment to the Company if the settlement price for any settlement&#13;period is below the floor price, the Company is required to make a payment to the counterparty if the settlement price for any&#13;settlement period is above the ceiling price and no payment is required by either party if the settlement price for any settlement&#13;period is between the floor price and the ceiling price.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;The Company&amp;#146;s derivative contracts are&#13;settled based on reported settlement prices on commodity exchanges, with crude oil derivative settlements based on NYMEX West Texas&#13;Intermediate (&amp;#147;WTI&amp;#148;) pricing.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;As of December 31, 2013, the Company had outstanding&#13;derivative contracts with respect to future production as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times

   &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt;    &lt;td colspan=3 style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;January 1, 2015 &amp;#150; December 31, 2015&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;24,000&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: bottom; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=vertical-align: top; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;88.28&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;  Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;As of December 31, 2013, the Company had total&#13;volume on open commodity swaps of 108,000 barrels at a weighted average price of approximately $92.69.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times

   &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;(213,676&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;&amp;#150;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 2.5pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;&lt;i&gt;&lt;u&gt;Balance sheet offsetting of derivative&#13;assets and liabilities&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;In December 2011, the FASB issued ASU No&#13;2011-11, Balance Sheet (Topic 210)-Disclosures about Offsetting Assets and Liabilities, which requires an entity to disclose&#13;information about offsetting arrangements to enable financial statement users to understand the effects of netting&#13;arrangements on an entity&amp;#146;s financial position. The Company adopted the provision of the standard upon entering into our&#13;first derivative contract and has provided the applicable disclosures below with respect to its derivative instruments.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify&gt;All of the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;derivative contracts are carried at their fair value in the condensed balance sheets under the captions &amp;#147;Current portion&#13;of derivative instruments&amp;#148; and &amp;#147;Derivative instruments&amp;#148;. Derivative instruments from the same&#13;counterparty that are subject to contractual terms which provide for net settlement are reported on a net basis in the&#13;condensed balance sheets. The following tables present the gross amounts of recognized derivative assets and liabilities, the&#13;amounts offset under the netting arrangements with counterparties, and the resulting net amounts presented in the condensed&#13;balance sheets for the periods presented, all at fair value.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style=font: 8pt Times New Roman
 Times
 Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=10 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;December 31, 2013&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=10 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;December 31, 2012&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Gross amounts of recognized assets&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; padding-bottom: 1pt;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan=2 style=border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: center&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Net amounts of liabilities on balance sheet&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-bottom: 1pt&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style=vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCFFCC&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=padding-left: 5.4pt&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;Commodity derivative liabilities&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style=text-align: right&gt;&lt;font style=font-size: 8pt&gt;(396,573&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;
